data.title: Our Mind On Music
data.meta_description: OurMindonMusic - All things music!                                                                               ………….. ……….Click a title to open a post that interests you.
data.text:
This week on the Our Mind On Music YouTube channel, I spoke with Demi Michelle Schwartz, a multifaceted talent from Pittsburgh, known for her achievements as a singer, songwriter, recording artist, author, publisher, and podcaster. Learn more about Demi Michelle, and her soon to be released album “Hear Me Out.”

Jeff Buckley’s debut and only studio album, Grace, was released on August 15, 1994, in Europe and on August 23, 1994, in the United States. Learn more here: Video and audio included.

In this blog post, we celebrate Allan Holdsworth’s extraordinary legacy, exploring his distinctive legato style and its impact on the world of guitar through his signature tracks. – Including a GUITARIST’S SUPPLEMENTAL: Practical exercises to Master Allan Holdsworth’s “Four-Notes-Per-String” (FNPS) Technique!

Janet Horvath is a cellist, author, and speaker with a remarkable career spanning decades. Born into a musical family in Toronto, she followed in her father’s footsteps to become an accomplished cellist. Janet Horvath served as the associate principal cello of the Minnesota Orchestra from 1980 to 2012, performing internationally as a soloist and recitalist.…

In the world of guitar playing, certain names resonate through the ages, but few have combined musical genius with a career in medicine quite like Vittorio Camardese. What? You don’t know the name? Well, I’ll come clean, either did I! Keep reading, to learn some amazing music history related to the evolution of guitar as…

Weather Report musicians: “Heavy Weather” received widespread critical acclaim when it was released, and is considered one of Weather Report’s most successful and influential works. It features a fusion of jazz, funk, and rock elements, showcasing the band’s virtuosity and innovative approach to music. “Birdland”: The album’s opening track, “Birdland,” became one of Weather Report’s…

In the early 1970s, one man’s voice dominated the airwaves, though few knew his name. Tony Burrows, often called “the man of a thousand voices,” achieved the remarkable feat of being the lead vocalist on six hit songs by different bands, all within a short span of time. Tony Burrows’ voice was everywhere on the…

Sound has the power to transport us to different worlds, evoke emotions, and enhance our entertainment experiences. The development of stereo sound, from its humble beginnings as Alan Blumlein’s binaural sound idea to today’s advanced stereophonic audio, has revolutionized the way we perceive and enjoy sound. This article explores the key figures, pivotal moments, and…

The Blattnerphone, developed by Ludwig Blattner in the late 1920s, was an early magnetic recording device that used steel tape. The Blattnerphone was one of the first technologies to enable high-quality recording and playback of music. The Blattnerphone was primarily used in radio broadcasting before being eventually replaced by magnetic tape recorders. The Blattnerphone allowed…

On July 15, drummers around the world celebrated the birthday of a true drumming pioneer – William F. Ludwig Sr., founder of Ludwig Drums, born on July 15, 1879. As the founder of Ludwig Drums, his innovations revolutionized the percussion world and left an indelible mark on the music industry. A Legacy of Innovation Ludwig’s…

In 1969, Linda Martell became the first Black woman to perform solo at the Grand Ole Opry. That same year, she released her debut single “Color Him Father,” which peaked at #22 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles chart – the highest-charting single by a Black female country artist until Beyoncé’s “Texas Hold ‘Em” in…

One of the core values of BIG Records is the belief that relationships and connections are key to an artist’s career, which is reflected in their approach to artist development and promotion.

Mark Rosner began his career in the music industry as a mixing engineer at White Ladder Music from January 2004 to January 2008. This four-year experience likely provided him with valuable technical skills and industry connections. After his time as a mixing engineer, Rosner transitioned into management and entrepreneurship. In January 2009, he founded Rosner…

The Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra (HK Phil) has announced its next Music Director: Finnish conductor Tarmo Peltokoski. At just 24 years old, Peltokoski will succeed Jaap van Zweden, taking the lead of one of Asia’s top orchestras.

Soon Hee Newbold is an impressive figure in the music world today. Her work embodies versatility and skill across multiple disciplines. As a violinist, composer, conductor, actress, producer, and screenwriter, Soon Hee Newbold’s talents seem boundless[1]. Her journey in music began at a young age, studying piano at five and violin at seven. Newbold’s prodigious…

The Michael Botte Band, born during the 2020 COVID-19 quarantine, has quickly become a force in the indie music scene. Fronted by Michael Botte, a Sony/Orchard and Big Records artist, the band draws from alt-country, rock and much more to create a unique sound that’s captivating audiences worldwide. At the heart of the band’s success…

“Faith No More” is an iconic alternative rock band known for its diverse and eclectic style, blending a wide variety of influences to create their unique sound. Formed in 1979, the band performed under the name “Sharp Young Men” before September 1983. Over the years, they seem to have seamlessly blended elements of rock, funk,…

Jennifer Turner is an American singer-songwriter, musician, and producer. She first gained recognition for her work as a guitarist and backing vocalist with Natalie Merchant on her multi-platinum album Tigerlily in the mid-1990s. Turner also played acoustic guitar on Mary J. Blige’s album Share My World.

2024 marks the 40th anniversary of Jake Dollery’s musical journey, which began when he first took to the stage fronting the band The Dead Legionnaires in 1987. Check out this blog and my video chat with Jake: https://youtu.be/ai5Z959hrMg

As we bring our three-part blog series to a close, we delve into the extraordinary success and lasting impact of the 1977 smash hit album, “Bat Out of Hell.”

Jim Steinman: Part 2 – Expanding the Musical Universe From “The Dream Engine” to “Neverland” (The Seeds that Grew into Bat Out of Hell)

A Vision Takes ShapeAs part of an Independent Studies project during his final year at Amherst College, Jim Steinman conceived, wrote, and scored a rock-n-roll musical known as “The Dream Engine.” Directed and choreographed by Barry Keating, the explosive production premiered in the spring of 1969, captivating audiences with its electrifying performances and thought-provoking narrative.…

The Guess Who, a legendary Canadian rock band who penned several hits like “American Woman” and “No Time,” made multiple memorable appearances on the pioneering music TV show “Upbeat,” filmed in Cleveland, Ohio in the early 1970s.

In the latest episode of “Our Mind on Music,” (Season 2, Episode 23) I have the pleasure of chatting with the incredibly talented, Ajantha; singer, songwriter, producer, dancer, and actor. Introducing Ajantha Ajantha is a dynamic and versatile artist whose achievements span various creative disciplines. Through our chat, Ajantha shares an inside look into her…

Not long ago, I posted an episode of my video podcast on YouTube. In which I spoke with a fantastic indie rocker, GrimRock. The episode quickly accumulated over 60 views, which, for my modest little podcast felt great. GrimRock even commented to me that he was happy with how quickly we had accumulated views. Shortly…

Yma Sumac captivated audiences with her unbelievable vocal range and unique blend of cultural influences. In fact, in 1956, she was recorded in the Guinness Book of World Records for having the “Greatest Range of Musical Value.”

April 21 marks a significant day in the world of music, as it commemorates the passing of the highly influential and remarkable artist, Nina Simone.

If IMPROVISING is like traveling with a map, but no itinerary, then maybe “John Coltrane’s Tone Circle” is the map.

Today, April 12, 2024, we join music lovers around the world in celebrating the 84th birthday of the legendary jazz pianist and composer, Herbie Hancock. With a career spanning over six decades, Herbie Hancock made significant contributions to the landscape of music. As we commemorate this special day, let’s take a moment to reflect on…

I have to admit, I’ve become a bit obsessed with Jim Steinman’s career. I have been a fan of Meatloaf since my earliest memories of music, but until I started research for an Our Mind on Music (OMoM) episode about the classic 1977 album, “Bat Out of Hell,” I had no idea how interesting and…

Billie Holiday – Born April 7, 1915: Billie Holiday, born Eleanora Fagan, stands as one of the most influential jazz singers of the 20th century. Her unique vocal style and emotive performances made her an icon in the music industry, and her impact on music still resonates today.

Posthumous albums have the power to evoke a sense of nostalgia and pay tribute to the artistic legacy of beloved musicians. From what I’ve heard so far, Glen Campbell’s “Duets” album is doing this for me. Although this posthumous release is scheduled for April 19, several tracks have been pre-released on streaming services. See links…

In this week’s episode, we have the pleasure of interviewing Stan Stewart (aka Stanley G), a talented musician from Muz4Now. Stan is known for his captivating piano improvisations and heartfelt compositions. Join us as we explore various aspects of his musical journey and gain valuable insights into the creative process, musical inspiration, and the life…

Max Webster was a Canadian rock band formed in Toronto in 1972. The band’s music blended elements of progressive rock, hard rock, and pop, creating a unique sound that set them apart from their contemporaries.

In this week’s episode, we have the pleasure of interviewing Stan Stewart (aka Stanley G), a talented musician from Muz4Now. Stan is known for his … Our Mind on Music Podcast: Interview with Stan Stewart (aka Stanley G) of Muz4Now

Michael Beinhorn is a multi-platinum record producer whose career has spanned over four decades, leaving an indelible mark on the music industry. His journey began in the late 1970s in New York City, during the emergence of the no wave genre, a short-lived but influential avant-garde music scene.No wave was an abrasive, experimental offshoot of…

The music industry is experiencing a revolution with spatial audio technologies like Dolby Atmos and Sony 360. These formats are transforming how we experience music, creating immersive, three-dimensional soundscapes that envelop listeners from all directions.

In a recent post, I gave an overview of the “Blattnerphone,” an audio recording device used for recording live performances to be transmitted on radio, such as the BBC in the 1920s. As a continuation of that blog post, this post looks briefly at the evolution of audio recording from the late 1920s to the…
